medical: PROCEDURES: Cystourethroscopy and transurethral resection of prostate. COMPLICATIONS: None. ADMITTING DIAGNOSIS: Difficulty voiding. HISTORY: This 67-year old Hispanic male patient was admitted because of enlarged prostate and symptoms of bladder neck obstruction. Physical examination revealed normal heart and lungs. Abdomen was negative for abnormal findings. LABORATORY DATA: BUN 19 and creatinine 1.1. Blood group was A, Rh positive, Hemoglobin 13, Hematocrit 32.1, Prothrombin time 12.6 seconds, PTT 37.1. Discharge hemoglobin 11.4, and hematocrit 33.3. Chest x-ray calcified old granulomatous disease, otherwise normal. EKG was normal. COURSE IN THE HOSPITAL: The patient had a cysto and TUR of the prostate. Postoperative course was uncomplicated. The pathology report is pending at the time of dictation. He is being discharged in satisfactory condition with a good urinary stream, minimal hematuria, and on Bactrim DS one a day for ten days with a standard postprostatic surgery instruction sheet. DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: Enlarged prostate with benign bladder neck obstruction. To be followed in my office in one week and by Dr. ABC next available as an outpatient.
layman:
**Procedures:** The patient had a cystourethroscopy and a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP).  
**Complications:** None.  

**Admitting diagnosis:** Difficulty urinating.  

**History:** A 67‑year‑old Hispanic man was admitted because his prostate was enlarged and he was having trouble emptying his bladder. A physical exam showed a normal heart and lungs, and his abdomen was normal.  

**Lab results:**  
- BUN 19, creatinine 1.1  
- Blood type A, Rh positive  
- Hemoglobin 13, hematocrit 32.1  
- Prothrombin time 12.6 s, PTT 37.1  

At discharge his hemoglobin was 11.4 and hematocrit 33.3.  

**Other tests:** Chest X‑ray showed old calcified granulomatous disease but otherwise normal. EKG was normal.  

**Hospital course:** The patient underwent the cystourethroscopy and TURP. He recovered without any problems. The pathology report is still pending. He is being sent home in good condition, with a clear urinary stream, only a little blood in the urine, and a prescription for Bactrim DS (two tablets) once a day for ten days. He also received a standard set of instructions for care after prostate surgery.  

**Discharge diagnosis:** Enlarged prostate causing benign bladder neck obstruction.  

He will see the office in one week and will be scheduled for a follow‑up with Dr. ABC at the next available appointment.
